p: We assumed exponentially-distributed latent and infectious periods (arising from rates of latency loss and recovery, respectively, being constant). Loss of latency rates γ 1, m were strain-dependent. From Lessler et al. [ 43], we chose rates corresponding to average latent periods of 1.4 days and 0.6 days for influenza A and influenza B associated strains respectively. Following Cauchemez et al. [ 44], we set the rate of loss of infectiousness γ 2 = 1/3.8, corresponding to an average infectious period of 3.8 days, independent of strain.
